(2 comments)

Agreed, but I don't think there is a great way to do this without restructuring the inheritance of the jobs, creating new ones and renaming others. I can try that, but this seems to be the minimal set of changes to get things running again."}, {'account_id': 28719, 'date': '2019-07-13 23:28:21.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 11.'}, {'account_id': 28719, 'date': '2019-07-14 01:19:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11:

The multinode jobs are failing because they are inheriting from the .zuul.yaml in the stable/stein patrole branch. Per the Zuul docs [0] this is expected. Depending on what the plan is for keeping stable/stein, that .zuul.yaml may also need to be updated. It may also make sense to remove the `branches:` specifications from some of the jobs.

Inheritance path from inventory.yaml [1]:

      - '<Job patrole-base-multinode branches: {MatchAny:{BranchMatcher:master}} source:
        openstack/patrole/.zuul.yaml@master#37>'
      - '<Job patrole-base-multinode branches: {MatchAny:{BranchMatcher:master}} source:
        openstack/patrole/.zuul.yaml@stable/stein#37>'
      - '<Job patrole-multinode-admin branches: {MatchAny:{BranchMatcher:master}}
        source: openstack/patrole/.zuul.yaml@master#128>'
      - '<Job patrole-multinode-admin branches: None source: openstack/patrole/.zuul.yaml@master#206>'

[0] https://zuul-ci.org/docs/zuul/user/config.html#configuration-loading
[1] http://logs.openstack.org/29/670229/11/check/patrole-multinode-admin/bd3c9d4/zuul-info/inventory.yaml"}, {'account_id': 28719, 'date': '2019-07-14 04:01:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 23186, 'date': '2019-07-14 14:36:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11: Code-Review+2

Thanks for doing this.'}, {'account_id': 23140, 'date': '2019-07-15 15:02:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11: Code-Review+1

Thanks Phil!'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2019-07-17 13:12:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-07-11 05:06:57.000000000', 'message': 'Zuul: Fix extra quotes when writing devstack localconf

When [0] introduced quoting all arguments, it broke the Zuul jobs
because the value of TEMPEST_PLUGINS is quoted. The fix [1] only
addressed extra double-quotes, not extra single-quotes.

This patchset changes from single to double quotes, which should
provide compatibility with all releases.

[0] https://review.opendev.org/636078
[1] https://review.opendev.org/648951

"}, {'created': '2019-07-11 23:55:18.000000000', 'message': "Zuul: Fix extra quotes when writing devstack localconf

Generate the correct TEMPEST_PLUGINS environment variable, working
around devstack's behavior of quoting all arguments [0]. For the
patrole-base and patrole-extension-base jobs, it is sufficient to
simply remove the quotes. For the multinode job, there is no way to
avoid quotes, and [1] is not able to remove extra single-quotes, so
we move to the new variable tempest_plugins introduced with [2].

[0] https://review.opendev.org/636078
[1] https://review.opendev.org/648951
[2] https://review.opendev.org/639374

Change-Id: I498c637da9dac7605851b2edbbfb302103c3d6a9

the new variable tempest_plugins introduced with [0], to get around
devstack's behavior of quoting all arguments [1]. Maintain the old
syntax for releases earlier than stein.

[0] https://review.opendev.org/639374
[1] https://review.opendev.org/636078

Change-Id: I498c637da9dac7605851b2edbbfb302103c3d6a9
"}]
commit_message:
Zuul: Fix extra quotes when writing devstack localconf

Generate the correct TEMPEST_PLUGINS environment variable, moving to
the new variable tempest_plugins introduced with [0], to get around
devstack's behavior of quoting all arguments [1]. Maintain the old
syntax for releases earlier than stein.

[0] https://review.opendev.org/639374
[1] https://review.opendev.org/636078

Change-Id: I498c637da9dac7605851b2edbbfb302103c3d6a9

* Add rest that is retired on *all* branches to legacy

commit_message:
Improve running prep validations using Ansible documentation

This patch adds some important export of ANSIBLE_* variables as the
validations playbooks are in their own playbooks directory and are not at
the same level as the libraries, plugins, roles ans so on.

Change-Id: I9f3e8344bc9dd69139e7fdef0cd1e88144fcd477
Signed-off-by: Gael Chamoulaud <gchamoul@redhat.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2016-01-13 20:39:33.000000000', 'message': 'Doc: Add rough plan for cellsv2 upgrade scenarios

out a rough plan for what it will look like to upgrade to cellsv2.

commit_message:
Doc: Add rough plan for cellsv2 upgrade scenarios

There are a lot of details to figure out and finalize, but this sketches
out a rough plan for what it will look like to upgrade to cellsv2.
Plans are provided for deployers starting with no cells or starting with
cellsv1.

Change-Id: If69fb904f8f38163f7180911cc52d0b64167f5f3

commit_message:
Add a suffix for tmpwatch

Change 641608 introduces tmpwatch into logrotate-crond container.
However, LogrotatePurgeAfterDays parameter is parsed in hours because
there is no suffix to the value. This commit adds a suffix, 'd' to the
value.

Closes-Bug: #1836848
Change-Id: I5e2c92a60f73b75a144228fd13ac31fff990a038

commit_message:
Add df-datapath2dot utility

Added df-datapath2dot untility to convert the datapath layout file to dot
format.
This can then be used to create a jpg/svg/etc. representation of the layout.

Change-Id: Iccc5edecfde9f720021c9396570b9d1face4f99e

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-07-08 15:20:52.000000000', 'message': "Wait for all compute services before cell discovery

There is a race condition during nova deploy since we wait for at least
one compute service to register itself before performing cells v2 host
discovery.  It's quite possible that other compute nodes will not yet
have registered and will therefore not be discovered. This leaves them
not mapped into a cell, and results in the following error if the
scheduler picks one when booting an instance:

Host 'xyz' is not mapped to any cell

The problem has been exacerbated by merging a fix [1][2] for a nova race
condition, which disabled the dynamic periodic discovery mechanism in
the nova scheduler.

This change fixes the issue by waiting for all expected compute services
to register themselves before performing host discovery. This includes
both virtualised compute services and bare metal compute services.

[1] https://bugs.launchpad.net/kolla-ansible/+bug/1832987
[2] https://review.opendev.org/665554

Change-Id: I2915e2610e5c0b8d67412e7ec77f7575b8fe9921
Closes-Bug: #1835002
(cherry picked from commit c38dd767118164aae37613d557ed23691813f617)
"}, {'created': '2019-07-09 09:39:04.000000000', 'message': "Wait for all compute services before cell discovery

There is a race condition during nova deploy since we wait for at least
one compute service to register itself before performing cells v2 host
discovery.  It's quite possible that other compute nodes will not yet
have registered and will therefore not be discovered. This leaves them
not mapped into a cell, and results in the following error if the
scheduler picks one when booting an instance:

Host 'xyz' is not mapped to any cell

The problem has been exacerbated by merging a fix [1][2] for a nova race
condition, which disabled the dynamic periodic discovery mechanism in
the nova scheduler.

This change fixes the issue by waiting for all expected compute services
to register themselves before performing host discovery. This includes
both virtualised compute services and bare metal compute services.

This patch also includes change I58f8fd0a6e82cb614e02fef6e5b271af1d1ce9af
which was made to fix an issue with the original version of this patch
running on Ansible<28. See bug 1835817 for details.

Change-Id: I2915e2610e5c0b8d67412e7ec77f7575b8fe9921
Closes-Bug: #1835002
(cherry picked from commit c38dd767118164aae37613d557ed23691813f617)
"}]
commit_message:
Wait for all compute services before cell discovery

There is a race condition during nova deploy since we wait for at least
one compute service to register itself before performing cells v2 host
discovery.  It's quite possible that other compute nodes will not yet
have registered and will therefore not be discovered. This leaves them
not mapped into a cell, and results in the following error if the
scheduler picks one when booting an instance:

Host 'xyz' is not mapped to any cell

The problem has been exacerbated by merging a fix [1][2] for a nova race
condition, which disabled the dynamic periodic discovery mechanism in
the nova scheduler.

This change fixes the issue by waiting for all expected compute services
to register themselves before performing host discovery. This includes
both virtualised compute services and bare metal compute services.

This patch also includes change I58f8fd0a6e82cb614e02fef6e5b271af1d1ce9af
which was made to fix an issue with the original version of this patch
running on Ansible<28. See bug 1835817 for details.

Change-Id: I2915e2610e5c0b8d67412e7ec77f7575b8fe9921
Closes-Bug: #1835002
(cherry picked from commit c38dd767118164aae37613d557ed23691813f617)

commit_message:
Bump Monasca Fluentd output plugin

This resolves an issue where the previous version of the plugin
would fail to re-send buffered logs if a post to the Monasca Log
API failed. With this new version of the plugin, logs are correctly
buffered and resent.

Change-Id: Ic1d93a8ea5f2571edfacf50809d51a8b77959a73
(cherry picked from commit d7e6c28272a2efddec8a1747067e4fdee4ff50ba)

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-07-05 09:26:20.000000000', 'message': "Define the Integrated-gate-placement gate template

tempest-full job run all services API and scenario tests (non slow)
and this job is part of Integrated-gate gate template which run on
multiple services (nova, neutron, cinder, glance, placement) check
and gate pipeline.

But there are many unrelated tests run on each project gate. For example,
neutron gate run cinder only tests and fail due to cinder bugs. There is
no point of breaking the neutron gate due to cinder only test failure and
slow down the neutron development phase.

This is what we dicussed in Train PTG in denver to improve the integrated
gate[1] and came up with idea of split the integated-gate template into
much logical way so that only dependent services tests run on their gate.

One way was to move the service only tests to service tempest plugin side
but Tempest is used by interop as well as on production cloud testing so
moving the test is not good idea.

This commit propose the idea of defining the 'Integrated-gate-placement'
gate template for placement gate which will run only nova and neutron tests.

ML discussion: http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-May/005871.html

Next step will be to replace the Integrated-gate-py3 template with new
Integrated-gate-placement template on neutron gate.

[1] https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/qa-train-ptg

Change-Id: I200197e2fb57879aaeb382266d6309f0d1137b0c
"}, {'created': '2019-07-05 09:30:57.000000000', 'message': "Define the Integrated-gate-placement gate template

tempest-full job run all services API and scenario tests (non slow)
and this job is part of Integrated-gate gate template which run on
multiple services (nova, neutron, cinder, glance, placement) check
and gate pipeline.

But there are many unrelated tests run on each project gate. For example,
neutron gate run cinder only tests and fail due to cinder bugs. There is
no point of breaking the neutron gate due to cinder only test failure and
slow down the neutron development phase.

This is what we dicussed in Train PTG in denver to improve the integrated
gate[1] and came up with idea of split the integated-gate template into
much logical way so that only dependent services tests run on their gate.

One way was to move the service only tests to service tempest plugin side
but Tempest is used by interop as well as on production cloud testing so
moving the test is not good idea.

This commit propose the idea of defining the 'Integrated-gate-placement'
gate template for placement gate which will run only nova and neutron tests.

ML discussion: http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-May/005871.html

Next step will be to replace the Integrated-gate-py3 template with new
Integrated-gate-placement template on neutron gate.

[1] https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/qa-train-ptg

Change-Id: I200197e2fb57879aaeb382266d6309f0d1137b0c

commit_message:
Define the Integrated-gate-placement gate template

tempest-full job run all services API and scenario tests (non slow)
and this job is part of Integrated-gate gate template which run on
multiple services (nova, neutron, cinder, glance, placement) check
and gate pipeline.

But there are many unrelated tests run on each project gate. For example,
neutron gate run cinder only tests and fail due to cinder bugs. There is
no point of breaking the neutron gate due to cinder only test failure and
slow down the neutron development phase.

This is what we dicussed in Train PTG in denver to improve the integrated
gate[1] and came up with idea of split the integated-gate template into
much logical way so that only dependent services tests run on their gate.

One way was to move the service only tests to service tempest plugin side
but Tempest is used by interop as well as on production cloud testing so
moving the test is not good idea.

This commit propose the idea of defining the 'Integrated-gate-placement'
gate template for placement gate which will run only nova and neutron tests.

ML discussion: http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-May/005871.html

Next step will be to replace the Integrated-gate-py3 template with new
Integrated-gate-placement template on placement gate.

[1] https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/qa-train-ptg

Change-Id: I200197e2fb57879aaeb382266d6309f0d1137b0c

use SqlFixture and StaticSqlFixture from neutron-lib

This patch replaces neutron's SqlFixture and StaticSqlFixture with
neutron-lib's and bumps the requirements and lower-constraints up to
use neutron-lib 1.28.0.

Change-Id: If707774cfa3e8b64685e2194ffe08a0fde7a42b2

This patch is re-registring the OVN metadata agent to its Chassis when the
entry is recreated. The Chassis entry gets deleted by the ovn-controller
process when it's gracefully shutdown and recreated when restarted.

Closes-Bug: #1835226
Change-Id: I18f1ff0832354ae8109323e5202e1681fc60a167
Signed-off-by: Lucas Alvares Gomes <lucasagomes@gmail.com>
"}]
commit_message:
OVN Metadata: Fix registration after Chassis entry is recreated

This patch is re-registring the OVN metadata agent to its Chassis when the
entry is recreated. The Chassis entry gets deleted by the ovn-controller
process when it's gracefully shutdown and recreated when restarted.

Closes-Bug: #1835226
Change-Id: I18f1ff0832354ae8109323e5202e1681fc60a167
Signed-off-by: Lucas Alvares Gomes <lucasagomes@gmail.com>

subject: Enable monasca-thresh to set topology.max.spout.pending f. Storm
messages:
[{'account_id': 16957, 'date': '2019-05-22 12:45:37.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10311, 'date': '2019-05-22 15:22:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

Change looks good, haven't tested it myself yet"}, {'account_id': 16222, 'date': '2019-05-29 08:29:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

(2 comments)

Have tested with SOC9 and set the topology.max.spout.pending to 100 and 500. I doesn't seem to solve the problem of high CPU consumption though.

Code looks good. Minor comments inline."}, {'account_id': 16957, 'date': '2019-05-29 13:56:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

@Witek: Are you sure topology.max.spout.pending has been used?
When I applied the change in my environment (using our system test), it didn't work at all. 
One possibility to check: start storm ui, and check via UI.
There, all settings can be checked"}, {'account_id': 16222, 'date': '2019-05-29 14:03:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Thanks, will retest.'}, {'account_id': 16957, 'date': '2019-05-29 14:05:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 16222, 'date': '2019-07-04 12:39:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I've checked to have correct configuration values with:

  # ./bin/storm localconfvalue topology.max.spout.pending
  topology.max.spout.pending: 500

I've run tempest tests with this setting on DevStack (Ubuntu) both locally and in CI [1]. All the tests have passed in both cases.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/668887"}, {'account_id': 16222, 'date': '2019-07-10 11:13:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I've repeated running the tempest tests locally with `topology.max.spout.pending` set to 5 and 1. In both cases all tests have passed."}, {'account_id': 16957, 'date': '2019-07-15 06:52:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1 -Workflow

Same setting has been tested extensively in a docker-setup.'}, {'account_id': 16222, 'date': '2019-07-15 07:46:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Could you address the inline comments? Other than that I'd say we're ready to merge."}, {'account_id': 17669, 'date': '2019-07-15 08:50:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

So for example, if we had very slow workers and a lot of metrics coming in, topology.max.spout.pending would have a significant effect. In this case the metrics would just sit in Kafka, rather than getting queued up in a pending state within Storm? The downside is that latency increases a bit, but probably not enough for us to care?

The change looks fine, but haven't had a chance to test yet. Thanks for looking at this."}, {'account_id': 17669, 'date': '2019-07-15 09:02:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Posting this for reference:

https://github.com/apache/storm/blob/master/docs/Performance.md

I guess you went through these options already? Since a lot of them depend on the deployment perhaps we should link to them in a separate change?'}, {'account_id': 16957, 'date': '2019-07-17 08:09:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Using topology.max.spout.pending resolved a concrete situation (using monasca-docker):

- monasca-server: rel. small machine (32 GB RAM?) 
- app. 60 metric agents were up and running
- monasca server was down for quite some time, i.e. agents buffered whatever they could
- When monasca-server has been restarted, agents were sending the measurements they stored internally
- Thus, thresholding engine created high memory and CPU-load.
My understanding: because of memory issues, GC was running frequently, but not freeing significant memory.
- Finally, monasca-thresh crashed.

We simulated this behavior by stopping monasca-thresh. Thus, a similar amount of entries was stored in kafka queue (7.5-15*10**6 entries).

I tested several options. With setting "topology.max.spout.pending", we were able to control the load for monasca-thresh/storm.
Besides, we executed further tests that showed that this change has no impact on system behavior under "normal" conditions.

I have NOT tested all possible settings, as described in your links.
I have NOT either reproduced the issue with devstack
I think, I found one solution that solves the problem we had, without impact on normal processing.
Without applying this change here (creation of unique id), setting "topology.max.spout.pending" has no impact.
Thus, I suggest that this change shall be applied.
Whether a concrete default value shall be set, can be discussed separately and is not part of this change.'}, {'account_id': 17669, 'date': '2019-07-17 08:34:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Thanks Matthias, that makes sense. Please can you make the minor changes that Witek has suggested?'}, {'account_id': 16957, 'date': '2019-07-17 10:06:12.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 16957, 'date': '2019-07-17 10:09:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 16222, 'date': '2019-07-17 11:24:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 17669, 'date': '2019-07-17 12:10:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]

topology.max.spout.pending allows to limit the number of concurrent
entries sent from spout to worker(s). However, this requires the
usage of a unique id when sending messages (emit).

Change-Id: I907a4574b80e7c3347ba6a9f12c7836767dc3dd7
Story: 2005471
Task: 30550
'}, {'created': '2019-07-17 10:06:12.000000000', 'message': 'Enable monasca-thresh to set topology.max.spout.pending f. Storm

topology.max.spout.pending allows to limit the number of concurrent
entries sent from spout to worker(s). However, this requires the
usage of a unique id when sending messages (emit).

Change-Id: I907a4574b80e7c3347ba6a9f12c7836767dc3dd7
Story: 2005471
Task: 30550
'}]
commit_message:
Enable monasca-thresh to set topology.max.spout.pending f. Storm

topology.max.spout.pending allows to limit the number of concurrent
entries sent from spout to worker(s). However, this requires the
usage of a unique id when sending messages (emit).

Change-Id: I907a4574b80e7c3347ba6a9f12c7836767dc3dd7
Story: 2005471

commit_message:
Add local bindep.txt and update sphinx logging

This is a combination of two commits to fix the check / gate jobs:

1. Add local bindep.txt

As it was announced [1] global bindep-fallback.txt was removed and now
projects need to have a local bindep.txt to be able to install binary
dependencies for testing.

In documentation zuul job graphviz package ('dot' command) is needed.
Without that the job fails with:
    dot command 'dot' cannot be run (needed for graphviz output),
    check the graphviz_dot setting

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-June/007272.html

(cherry picked from commit feac47186d79569bb564e18216e07f18ed5ccd8b)
(cherry picked from commit caf65ed26066b5f7d13cc50e67f1df852414b2dc)

2. Update sphinx logging to not use app object

Logging via the application object was deprecated in sphinx 1.6 and is
now removed in the master branch that will become 2.0. This updates our
sphinx extension to use the recommended sphinx.util.logging instead.

Closes-bug: #1798174
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>
(cherry picked from commit 5b39123aa4d2988fc773003d166c2bde590ea080)

Change-Id: I5efddfc72e9dc0dd1b8b9e1e37708e1d30ef3c39

subject: [DO NOT SUBMIT] Hide debug logs in Kafka lib
messages:
[{'account_id': 21922, 'date': '2018-09-27 12:50:03.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 21922, 'date': '2018-09-28 06:34:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 21922, 'date': '2018-09-28 07:27:20.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 21922, 'date': '2018-09-28 07:48:28.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 28062, 'date': '2018-09-28 08:02:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

It is possible to hide only the debug-logs generated by kafka_lib by increasing the log level to info and leaving the rest of logs of this module in the original debug level.

A configuration example for that looks like:

vagrant@devstack:~$ cat  /etc/monasca/events-persister-logging.conf
[loggers]
keys = root, kafka, kafka.consumer

[handlers]
keys = console, file

[formatters]
keys = generic

[logger_root]
level = DEBUG
formatter = default
handlers = console, file

[logger_kafka.consumer]
qualname = kafka.consumer
level = INFO
formatter = default
handlers = console, file
propagate = 0

[logger_kafka]
qualname = monasca_common.kafka_lib
level = INFO
formatter = default
handlers = console, file
propagate = 0

[handler_console]
class = logging.StreamHandler
args = (sys.stderr,)
level = DEBUG
formatter = generic

[handler_file]
class = logging.handlers.RotatingFileHandler
level = DEBUG
formatter = generic
# store up to 5*100MB of logs
args = ('/var/log/monasca/events/events-persister.log', 'a', 104857600, 5)

[formatter_generic]
format = %(asctime)s %(levelname)s [%(name)s][%(threadName)s] %(message)s


*** Note that the logger's name in files client.py, conn.py and consumer/simple.py is logging.getLogger(__name__)
but in /consumer/base.py and /producer/base.py it is hardcoded to logging.getLogger('kafka.consumer'), that's why the section logger_kafka.consumer is needed as well."}, {'account_id': 21922, 'date': '2018-10-10 06:45:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Workflow-1'}]

commit_message:
[DO NOT SUBMIT] Hide debug logs in Kafka lib

They are producing too much useless logs that make debugging hard.

Change-Id: Ied15b4ee61e4c6b247a2394bcc81be43f451e378

commit_message:
Debian/Ubuntu: move to Python 3 for source images

Commit 43b74ccc157c0b50138c3785ed91dab504895571 enabled use of Python 3
based packages but not switched to use Python 3.

Some of images still contain Python 2. There are two reasons:

- Ceph (ceph-common depends on Py2)
- python3-ldappool on Ubuntu 18.04

In Ceph situation Py3 packages were added. For second one we can not do
anything - Py2 dependency got dropped in Ubuntu 18.10 version.

Removed neutron-server-plugin-networking-infoblox due to being not
maintained. Once https://review.opendev.org/#/c/657578/ get merged
someone may revert that part.

Implements: blueprint debian-ubuntu-python3

Depends-on: Ie2a1077f7def0743f1403341985e2109aa490026

Change-Id: Ibfe0c2b8be98db56c61f74fb0247488ab3749ef4
(cherry picked from commit d436001b43f0a7e3c161ac4a2c5d09d36c6f1015 and
edited to apply:
- kolla/common/config.py s/master/versionnumbers
- docker/cinder-volume/Dockerfile.j2 change was already there
)

commit_message:
Optionally tag newly created images

Make the tag configurable instead of being a compulsory hard coded
one.

commit_message:
Improve logging of retrofit activities

Log that action is being run and result of it.

Log successfull creation of image with name and ID.

Log output from ``octavia-diskimage-retrofit`` command, this will
be important in the event of error and/or debugging in the wild
error conditions.

Change-Id: Ic393e027759570bdd9d1ce1c4d24a9b5b4697d59

commit_message:
Use systemd-journald instead of log files

This patch aims to migrate service from usage of regular syslog files
to journald. We also disable uwsgi logging, since it dublicates
requests that are logged by service itself.

Change-Id: Iaddb2c158a52d90025899d9bfa5576358bef92dd

for all of the Tested Runtimes for Train.

subject: Correct endpoint_override discovery for service with dashes in their type
messages: [{'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2019-07-16 16:20:43.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 2, 'date': '2019-07-16 16:23:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 29745, 'date': '2019-07-16 17:43:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 27900, 'date': '2019-07-17 08:46:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-07-16 16:20:43.000000000', 'message': 'Correct endpoint_override discovery for service with dashes in their type

Currently when handling endpoint_override, we correctly discover the
actual URL, but then we populate the wrong configuration option (with
a dash instead of an underscore). This results in the unversioned URL
being used for requests, breaking ironic-inspector with endpoint_override.

Change-Id: Id8d68a8b544cb557cfbd3e38bee93bcf88f673ed
'}]
commit_message:
Correct endpoint_override discovery for service with dashes in their type

Currently when handling endpoint_override, we correctly discover the
actual URL, but then we populate the wrong configuration option (with
a dash instead of an underscore). This results in the unversioned URL
being used for requests, breaking ironic-inspector with endpoint_override.

Change-Id: Id8d68a8b544cb557cfbd3e38bee93bcf88f673ed

@Jordan:I'd like clarify some:
> The new test is slow (boot/reboot/ssh) and duplicates some code. I think you can refactor both test_server_basicops and test_boot_server_basic_ops_with_specified_host to avoid duplicating the call to add_keypair, create_security_group, pause_server, unpause_server etc...

Yes, I can refactor some code. But I think it needs to execute add_keypair, create_security_group etc.. in test_server_basicops and test_boot_server_basic_ops_with_specified_host individually. Because they are different credentials. Does this make sense?


> I also think test_boot_server_basic_ops_with_specified_host could be skipped if CONF.scenario.boot_hosts_filter is empty.

"EMPTY STRING" means 'ALL compute nodes'. This is a specification of this test :). Do you mean we should skip this test if CONF.scenario.boot_hosts_filter is empty?'}, {'account_id': 5689, 'date': '2014-03-05 10:04:37.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 12.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-03-05 10:04:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

http://status.openstack.org/zuul/'}, {'account_id': 7350, 'date': '2014-03-05 10:06:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

You can add a new function (not a test) with one parameter (this parameter would be a switch to either call boot_instance() or boot_instance_with_specified_host). This function would wrap all the calls to add_keypair/create_security_group/pause_server with the correct compute_client (either admin or non-admin)

Then the two tests test_server_basicops and test_boot_server_basic_ops_with_specified_host would call this previous function with 2 different values for the parameter.

>"EMPTY STRING" means 'ALL compute nodes'. This is a specification of this test :). Do you mean we should skip this test if CONF.scenario.boot_hosts_filter is empty?

Yes, that's what I meant. 'ALL compute nodes' is basically what the basic test test_server_basicops() do, I think.'}, {'account_id': 7350, 'date': '2014-03-05 10:07:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

I actually do think that cross-AZ testing is important and needs to be added to Tempest, but I'm -1 on adding this to the basic ops tests in scenarios.

I think we need a wholly separate test case for this."}, {'account_id': 7350, 'date': '2014-03-14 09:16:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

@Jay, creating a seperate test case would duplicate a lot of code. If we create a new separate file for each variation of a scenario we would end up with a tonne of files.

If there is more AZ tests to do, then at that time, we could  split/refactor the tests.'}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2014-03-14 11:43:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

agree with Jay, also, is this meaningfully tested in the gate in any way?"}, {'account_id': 5689, 'date': '2014-03-18 06:49:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12:

@Sean
> agree with Jay, also, is this meaningfully tested in the gate in any way?

Actually, this test is almost the same as TestServerBasicOps for now in the gate. But in the near future, I think the gate will have multiple AZs and compute nodes. If so, this is very meaningful in the gate.
And, in the production environments, they have already multiple AZs and compute nodes. So I think this test is useful for their environments.

Anyway, I'll update this test case as a new test class.

Thanks!"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-03-18 06:49:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: No score

commit_message:
Add a test for booting instances at the specified AZs or hosts

This test is booting instances for specified AZs or hosts with
tempest.conf. This is useful for verifying specific nodes such as
newly added, repaired and so on.

Change-Id: I8a668f8ae7bbba19418ad9ef8ce16cb227e7046a
Partially-Implements: blueprint add-scenario-tests-in-icehouse

commit_message:
Use SessionClient for Ironic actions

The HTTPClient for Ironic is deprecated and will be removed in Stein.
Use the SessionClient for Ironic actions instead. Also uses
endpoint_override param instead of endpoint, as that is also
deprecated.

Change-Id: Ida3b502b25887ec9a7b51c4d6497699cc9466f05

subject: Add caching for knownhost private-address lookups
messages: [{'account_id': 20870, 'date': '2019-07-16 13:27:50.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 20870, 'date': '2019-07-16 21:02:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:\n\ncharm-recheck-full'}, {'account_id': 935, 'date': '2019-07-17 08:52:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-07-16 13:27:50.000000000', 'message': 'Add caching for knownhost private-address lookups

This change adds caching for the host look ups associated with a
private-address of a unit.  This cache is maintained across hook
invocations, and is designed to reduce the time spent in
cloud-compute-relation-changed hooks (which occur as nova-compute units
join and update on the cloud-compute relation).

The feature has been added under an EXPERIMENTAL config flag (with the
default being "don't use the cached values") in case there are any
corner cases around DNS resolution in the deploying cloud during
deployment.

An action is included to allow clearing of the cache at unit,
application and whole relation level.  This clears the cache and
re-triggers the host resolution, and relation updates.  This is in case
of either 1) DNS changed during the deployment, 2) DNS has been altered
during the running of the cloud.

Change-Id: I5a68bf4c30bf1591184d660d50559c969822ddcf
'}]
commit_message:
Add caching for knownhost private-address lookups

This change adds caching for the host look ups associated with a
private-address of a unit.  This cache is maintained across hook
invocations, and is designed to reduce the time spent in
cloud-compute-relation-changed hooks (which occur as nova-compute units
join and update on the cloud-compute relation).

The feature has been added under an EXPERIMENTAL config flag (with the
default being "don't use the cached values") in case there are any
corner cases around DNS resolution in the deploying cloud during
deployment.

An action is included to allow clearing of the cache at unit,
application and whole relation level.  This clears the cache and
re-triggers the host resolution, and relation updates.  This is in case
of either 1) DNS changed during the deployment, 2) DNS has been altered
during the running of the cloud.

Change-Id: I5a68bf4c30bf1591184d660d50559c969822ddcf

commit_message:
Refactor compute hostname resolving functionality

The main driver here is to separate the concerns of resolving host names
and adding them to service/user related files.  This is to enable the
(eventual) resolution of the feature to allow migrations across
relation ids (i.e. between nova-compute applications) and to enable
caching of hostname look ups.

Change-Id: I406d1daacbcc74eb6f3e090f9a46e01dd3e19cc8

commit_message:
Use ansible_pkg_mgr fact instead of hardcoding yum command

This patch adds support for 'dnf' and 'yum' command in the repos role by
using the 'ansible_pkg_mgr' fact.

Change-Id: I5f9ea00d8c2c438b16d28f7de91c2ac79fd01228
Signed-off-by: Gael Chamoulaud <gchamoul@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Delete dhcp ports totally during scale down of dhcp agents

When we scale down the dhcp agent, such as from 4 to 3,
neutron-server will remove network from one dhcp agent. However,
it will remain a 'reserved_dhcp_port' in DB and result in dnsmasq
config still records this port ip in opts file.

Change-Id: Ie289ac8e8f2bb2748ac3c8656d82f80aa8660f24
Closes-Bug: #1739219

commit_message:
Update unified limit documentation

- Fix minor grammatical issues
- Include the `strict_two_level` model in the enforcement model
  section
- Improve readability
- Add enforcement examples in the form of diagrams

for all of the Tested Runtimes for Train.

See the Train python3-updates goal document for details:

commit_message:
Rename iptables-based active-standby jobs

Rename jobs so that it does not conflict with amphora stats-based
active-standby jobs being added in
Ibcd5552a67cea650edc72bfaa986357267ca2407 and will become default
active-standby jobs from Rocky.

Change-Id: Ie61f42f0d5565455a766b321055f0b854820a865

commit_message:
Use systemd-journald instead of log files

This patch aims to migrate service from usage of regular syslog files
to journald. We also disable uwsgi logging, since it dublicates
requests that are logged by service itself.

Change-Id: I3f6a1cee0e98372881b015ebf06e405c79495fe1

commit_message:
Add bind mount for config setup

Add missing bind mount for /var/named-persistent which is required by
named validation:

https://github.com/theforeman/puppet-dns/commit/526d4db3e3f3106f95dffdd47e8b34a8a6278eca

Closes-Bug: #1836812
Change-Id: I3dc654634bfe97bf0a53ba4014b5cbf4008bb134

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-05-06 10:37:53.000000000', 'message': 'nova-libvirt: in Debian qemu-kvm is x86 only

This package provides just a wrapper script /usr/bin/kvm which run
qemu-system-x86 in kvm mode for backwards compatibility.

Change-Id: I0cc03a1ab5a79ae49fa7d13ac549e21d3ec5295d
'}]
commit_message:
nova-libvirt: in Debian qemu-kvm is x86 only

This package provides just a wrapper script /usr/bin/kvm which run
qemu-system-x86 in kvm mode for backwards compatibility.

Change-Id: I0cc03a1ab5a79ae49fa7d13ac549e21d3ec5295d

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
and resubmit a new change-set.

Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
Workflow: https://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html

Hi, For the commit message, we can reference this:
Summary of Git commit message structure
Provide a brief description of the change in the first line.
Insert a single blank line after the first line.
Provide a detailed description of the change in the following lines, breaking paragraphs where needed.
The first line should be limited to 50 characters and should not end with a period.
Subsequent lines should be wrapped at 72 characters.
vim (the default $EDITOR on most distros) can wrap automatically lines for you. In most cases you just need to copy the example vimrc file (which can be found somewhere like /usr/share/vim/vim74/vimrc_example.vim) to ~/.vimrc if you don't have one already.
After editing a paragraph, you can re-wrap it by pressing escape, ensuring the cursor is within the paragraph and typing gqip.
Put the 'Change-id', 'Story: xxxx', and 'Task: yyyy' (or 'Closes-Bug #NNNNN' and 'blueprint NNNNNNNNNNN' if the project still uses Launchpad) lines at the very end.
Link: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages"}, {'account_id': 29729, 'date': '2019-07-04 01:35:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

commit_message:
Add 'local_gb' disk quota support

This adds support for microversion 2.52 which allows
manipulating a quota resource 'local_gb'.

Change-Id: Ib50333c500725da2562d2c717f7bec67e30c898b
Depends-On: I46aea29e76e4b4907d1db295d461237040f5eacf
Implements BluePrint nova-disk-quota-tracking

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-11-15 07:45:21.000000000', 'message': 'Check for volume size

Add check to ensure volume size specified by user
is greater than the image size in the boot from volume. If this is
not checked upfront, the VM calls cinder to attach a volume with given
OS installed which is not available because of the size constraint. So
this VM goes into the error state. This check informs the user about the
issue upfront and prevents the VM from going into error state.

Change-Id: I004f391344f88360c684861b25afb0d337bac9a3
Closes-Bug: 1465947
'}]
commit_message:
Check for volume size

Add check to ensure volume size specified by user
is greater than the image size in the boot from volume. If this is
not checked upfront, the VM calls cinder to attach a volume with given
OS installed which is not available because of the size constraint. So
this VM goes into the error state. This check informs the user about the
issue upfront and prevents the VM from going into error state.

Change-Id: I004f391344f88360c684861b25afb0d337bac9a3
Closes-Bug: 1465947

commit_message:
Add Python 3 Train unit tests

This is a mechanically generated patch to ensure unit testing is in place
for all of the Tested Runtimes for Train.

See the Train python3-updates goal document for details:
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/train/python3-updates.html

Change-Id: I4416ad8c1dc7f7414981eb7e82c88d18fc2ff9a7
Story: #2005924
Task: #34222

commit_message:
Fix gate error "mysqladmin: command not found"

mysqladmin package is required in tools/test-setup.sh
so adding bindep.txt file for this binary dependencies

- http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-June/007272.html

Change-Id: I6e624fe1b99a6257147deb694e0da87590e4102e

Additionally, this has unit test fixes for a CephContext
update and a Keystone V3 update that came with this sync.

messages:
[{'account_id': 30691, 'date': '2019-07-16 16:44:07.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10068, 'date': '2019-07-16 16:44:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
and resubmit a new change-set.

Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
Workflow: https://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html
Commit Messages: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages"}, {'account_id': 30691, 'date': '2019-07-16 16:45:53.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 30691, 'date': '2019-07-16 17:24:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-07-16 16:44:07.000000000', 'message': '   Author: Mauricio Tavares <raubvogel@gmail.com>

   Increases the level of detail provided by the debug messages in
pci_passthrough_filter.py.

Current debug output when pci passthrough filter test fails is something like
this:

```
2019-06-26 14:25:35.513 14352 DEBUG nova.scheduler.filters.pci_passthrough_filter
[req-b5e116b8-e852-4b95-a72f-a56c111afdee 7808c002b9784def81d8a20b63a14b62
93c6cce5fae8427bb4030a3eb8f43d4a - default default] (openstack-w1.example.com,
openstack-w1.example.com) ram: 63334MB disk: 124928MB io_ops: 0 instances: 3
doesn't have the required PCI devices (InstancePCIRequests(instance_uuid=417592b3-71a1-485a-8209-a7e01fc7ad32,requests=[InstancePCIRequest]))
host_passes /usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/nova/scheduler/filters/pci_passthrough_filter.py:57
```

In other words, it output the list of PCI devices requested as an instance_uuid
thingie. If you look at the comments in the `pci_passthrough_filter.py` file,

```
    Filter that schedules instances on a host if the host has devices
    to meet the device requests in the 'extra_specs' for the flavor.

    PCI resource tracker provides updated summary information about the
    PCI devices for each host, like::

        | [{"count": 5, "vendor_id": "8086", "product_id": "1520",
        |   "extra_info":'{}'}],

   and VM requests PCI devices via PCI requests, like::

        | [{"count": 1, "vendor_id": "8086", "product_id": "1520",}].
```

it implies the requests and pci device avilable in a host are lists. I propose
not only to output the pci device request as a list

```
2019-07-12 18:38:03.651 17858 DEBUG nova.scheduler.filters.pci_passthrough_filter
[req-50f5cfa4-c233-437e-8c53-dca760abb1c6 7808c002b9784def81d8a20b63a14b62
93c6cce5fae8427bb4030a3eb8f43d4a - default default] (openstack-w1.example,
openstack-w1.example.com) ram: 64870MB disk: 125952MB io_ops: 0 instances: 0
doesn't have the required PCI devices ([InstancePCIRequest(alias_name='Netronome',
count=1,is_new=<?>,numa_policy='legacy',request_id=None,requester_id=<?>,
spec=[{dev_type='type-PCI',product_id='4000',vendor_id='19ee'}])]) host_passes
/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/nova/scheduler/filters/pci_passthrough_filter.py:57
```

but also the list of pci devices in the host,

```
2019-07-02 18:38:03.789 16776 DEBUG nova.scheduler.filters.pci_passthrough_filter
[req-3fe1e6c3-6199-4abb-86e6-486386d67522 7808c002b9784def81d8a20b63a14b62
93c6cce5fae8427bb4030a3eb8f43d4a - default default] (openstack-w1.example.com,
openstack-w1.example.com) ram: 64870MB disk: 128000MB io_ops: 0 instances: 0
list of PCI devices: ([{'count': 1, 'product_id': u'4000', u'dev_type':
u'type-PF', 'numa_node': 0, 'vendor_id': u'19ee'}]) host_passes
/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/nova/scheduler/filters/pci_passthrough_filter.py:55
```

so someone trying to figure out why the pci passthrough filter failed can
see exactly what is being asked and what the host have. In this example,
the dev-type was wrongly set to `type-PCI` in `nova.conf` file. With this
patch, we can see exactly what nova thinks the card in question is.

Change-Id: I765d7bd735cffafb17369cae41e1cc23334363f2

commit_message:
Increases the level of detail provided by the debug messages in
pci_passthrough_filter.py.

Current debug output when pci passthrough filter test fails is something like
this:

```
2019-06-26 14:25:35.513 14352 DEBUG
nova.scheduler.filters.pci_passthrough_filter
[req-b5e116b8-e852-4b95-a72f-a56c111afdee 7808c002b9784def81d8a20b63a14b62
93c6cce5fae8427bb4030a3eb8f43d4a - default default]
(openstack-w1.example.com, openstack-w1.example.com) ram: 63334MB disk:
124928MB io_ops: 0 instances: 3 doesn't have the required PCI devices
(InstancePCIRequests(instance_uuid=417592b3-71a1-485a-8209-a7e01fc7ad32,requests=[InstancePCIRequest]))
host_passes
/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/nova/scheduler/filters/pci_passthrough_filter.py:57
```

In other words, it output the list of PCI devices requested as an instance_uuid
thingie. If you look at the comments in the `pci_passthrough_filter.py` file,

```
    Filter that schedules instances on a host if the host has devices
    to meet the device requests in the 'extra_specs' for the flavor.

    PCI resource tracker provides updated summary information about the
    PCI devices for each host, like::

        | [{"count": 5, "vendor_id": "8086", "product_id": "1520",
        |   "extra_info":'{}'}],

   and VM requests PCI devices via PCI requests, like::

        | [{"count": 1, "vendor_id": "8086", "product_id": "1520",}].
```

it implies the requests and pci device avilable in a host are lists. I propose
not only to output the pci device request as a list

```
2019-07-12 18:38:03.651 17858 DEBUG
nova.scheduler.filters.pci_passthrough_filter
[req-50f5cfa4-c233-437e-8c53-dca760abb1c6 7808c002b9784def81d8a20b63a14b62
93c6cce5fae8427bb4030a3eb8f43d4a - default default] (openstack-w1.example,
openstack-w1.example.com) ram: 64870MB disk: 125952MB io_ops: 0 instances:
0 doesn't have the required PCI devices
([InstancePCIRequest(alias_name='Netronome',
count=1,is_new=<?>,numa_policy='legacy',request_id=None,requester_id=<?>,
spec=[{dev_type='type-PCI',product_id='4000',vendor_id='19ee'}])])
host_passes
/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/nova/scheduler/filters/pci_passthrough_filter.py:57
```

but also the list of pci devices in the host,

```
2019-07-02 18:38:03.789 16776 DEBUG
nova.scheduler.filters.pci_passthrough_filter
[req-3fe1e6c3-6199-4abb-86e6-486386d67522 7808c002b9784def81d8a20b63a14b62
93c6cce5fae8427bb4030a3eb8f43d4a - default default]
(openstack-w1.example.com, openstack-w1.example.com) ram: 64870MB disk:
128000MB io_ops: 0 instances: 0 list of PCI devices: ([{'count': 1,
'product_id': u'4000', u'dev_type': u'type-PF', 'numa_node': 0,
'vendor_id': u'19ee'}]) host_passes
/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/nova/scheduler/filters/pci_passthrough_filter.py:55
```

so someone trying to figure out why the pci passthrough filter failed can
see exactly what is being asked and what the host have. In this example,
the dev-type was wrongly set to `type-PCI` in `nova.conf` file. With this
patch, we can see exactly what nova thinks the card in question is.

Author: Mauricio Tavares <raubvogel@gmail.com>
Change-Id: I765d7bd735cffafb17369cae41e1cc23334363f2

commit_message:
Convert dynamic includes to static imports

When task/role files are included using include_tasks, tags are not
passed to the included tasks. As a result, tags like neutron-config
do not have the intended effect. This patch changes include_tasks
to import_tasks for all cases where dynamic vars or loops are not used
so that tags are properly handled.

Reference -
https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/latest/user_guide/playbooks_reuse.html
https://bugs.launchpad.net/openstack-ansible/+bug/1815043

Change-Id: I3acc79b933b7068a13f8c09daff16f0b6920e834

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-07-15 11:14:03.000000000', 'message': 'Fix race in test_keepalived_state_change_notification

In case if initial keepalived status find in
keepalived_state_change.MonitorDaemon is "master"
this test_keepalived_state_change_notification was failing
because there was 4 calls to the mocked enqueue_state_change()
method instead of 3.

This patch changes test to wait until 3 or 4 calls to this
method will be counted and it also changes assertions of
what state should be set on which call.
Before the patch test was expecting that calls are always like:
backup, master, backup
but if there are 4 calls it is like: backup, master, master, backup.
As it doesn't matter if there was one or two calls with "master"
state, test will now assert that the last call is always with
"backup" state.

Change-Id: I78c30ab32ffda37176a9c71348d83e17ab2c972a
Closes-Bug: #1836565
'}]
commit_message:
Fix race in test_keepalived_state_change_notification

In case if initial keepalived status find in
keepalived_state_change.MonitorDaemon is "master"
this test_keepalived_state_change_notification was failing
because there was 4 calls to the mocked enqueue_state_change()
method instead of 3.

This patch changes test to wait until 3 or 4 calls to this
method will be counted and it also changes assertions of
what state should be set on which call.
Before the patch test was expecting that calls are always like:
backup, master, backup
but if there are 4 calls it is like: backup, master, master, backup.
As it doesn't matter if there was one or two calls with "master"
state, test will now assert that the last call is always with
"backup" state.

Change-Id: I78c30ab32ffda37176a9c71348d83e17ab2c972a
Closes-Bug: #1836565

commit_message:
Add local bindep.txt and limit bandit version

As it was announced [1] global bindep-fallback.txt was removed and now
projects need to have a local bindep.txt to be able to install binary
dependencies for testing.

In test jobs the script tools/test-setup.sh is called which requires
mysql and postgres servers and clients to be installed.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-June/007272.html

(cherry picked from commit d116b216965bbfc80840f5bfc994b731e2d29d81)

Note(elod.illes): patch was modified so that the test-requires files
are kept. An upper constraint was also added for bandit. This actually
freezes requirements (required by bandit) on stable branch.

Change-Id: If9befe4115c64c2fda52321002ba5fe1124eaf7c
(cherry picked from commit 916fd05627dddce33a577038f983e17295cc44e8)
(cherry picked from commit ec50bb8fa46f909d642f1f3af4f3c3d558d11de8)
(cherry picked from commit 478f752ee4a01bc9f03d99af7e15980b9e45c2db)

commit_message:
Add local bindep.txt and limit bandit version

As it was announced [1] global bindep-fallback.txt was removed and now
projects need to have a local bindep.txt to be able to install binary
dependencies for testing.

In test jobs the script tools/test-setup.sh is called which requires
mysql and postgres servers and clients to be installed.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-June/007272.html

(cherry picked from commit d116b216965bbfc80840f5bfc994b731e2d29d81)

Change-Id: I2492ed205a94541160e72a9cb3631e0b255d5b53
'}]
commit_message:
Convert dynamic includes to static imports

When task/role files are included using include_tasks, tags are not
passed to the included tasks. As a result, tags like neutron-config
do not have the intended effect. This patch changes include_tasks
to import_tasks for all cases where dynamic vars or loops are not used
so that tags are properly handled.

Reference -
https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/latest/user_guide/playbooks_reuse.html
https://bugs.launchpad.net/openstack-ansible/+bug/1815043

Change-Id: I2492ed205a94541160e72a9cb3631e0b255d5b53

(1 comment)

The purpose of this patch is not to rename the MSA driver, but to fix problems with the data entry when the file was created.  There is no such thing as an "hpe mmsa".

The driver name reflects the product for which the driver was created--it supports both both the original HP MSA and the newer HPE MSA products.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-07-11 18:35:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

commit_message:
Update support matrix entries for MSA and Lenovo arrays.

Declared support for multi-attach in these arrays, and fixed a typo
("mmsa" => "msa").  Note that this was not a driver rename, just a data
entry error when the file was created.

Change-Id: I796c7458514d12e277c77311ff1b91a88fcd9212
Closes-Bug: #1836080

commit_message:
Set default value for keystone_auth_default_policy

A default value for keystone_auth_default_policy is needed when using
label keystone_auth_enabled=false during creating k8s cluster, otherwise
it will fail because of missing the default value. This patch fixes it.

Story: 2005915
Task: 34175

Change-Id: I465725ecd55bf7c4dccaa75a8cd23c59a5be8db0

> (5 comments)

Everything you've said kind of makes sense, but I've no idea where to even start implementing this and I fear we'll see the same issues with os-vif objects that I described in an earlier patchset.

Would it be possible to merge this as-is, unblocking the rest of the stack, and I'll happily rework again if you suggest what these should look like, assuming that's possible."}, {'account_id': 9708, 'date': '2019-07-15 16:12:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

> > (5 comments)
 > >
 > > While I definitely support removing getattr calls I think what we
 > > logically have in the code is an interface and many
 > implementations
 > > of that interface. So we can even take a step further and replace
 > > the isinstance / vif_type dependent if-elses as well with
 > > polymorphism.
 > 
 > Everything you've said kind of makes sense, but I've no idea where
 > to even start implementing this and I fear we'll see the same
 > issues with os-vif objects that I described in an earlier patchset.
 > 
 > Would it be possible to merge this as-is, unblocking the rest of
 > the stack, and I'll happily rework again if you suggest what these
 > should look like, assuming that's possible.

Sure.

My current thinking: 
We have vif objects from os-vif lib but those object does not want to be libvirt specific. Therefore the libvirt driver adds extra "extension methods" for the vif objects to generate the libvirt xml fragment for the vif. I think we can wrap the os-vif object created in _nova_to_osvif_*() functions with libvirt specific classes. And those libvirt specific classes can implement the generic get_config, set_config, plug, unplug interface. We need to move some code around from LibvirtGenericVIFDriver to the specific vif wrappers or a base class of those. But It feels doable. Ping me if you stuck with such a refactor I will try to help.'}, {'account_id': 11604, 'date': '2019-07-16 22:21:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

 > 
 > Sure.
 > 
 > My current thinking:
 > We have vif objects from os-vif lib but those object does not want
 > to be libvirt specific. Therefore the libvirt driver adds extra
 > "extension methods" for the vif objects to generate the libvirt xml
 > fragment for the vif. I think we can wrap the os-vif object created
 > in _nova_to_osvif_*() functions with libvirt specific classes. And
 > those libvirt specific classes can implement the generic
 > get_config, set_config, plug, unplug interface. We need to move
 > some code around from LibvirtGenericVIFDriver to the specific vif
 > wrappers or a base class of those. But It feels doable. Ping me if
 > you stuck with such a refactor I will try to help.

our instead of hacking it ourselves since we will have os-vif objects we can use PEP 443 -- Single-dispatch generic functions
https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0443/ which introduces function overlading based the first arguemetn type it was technically added in python 3.4  but its been backported to 2.7 as a library
https://pypi.org/project/singledispatch/
and it already in upperconstratints so we can use it. https://opendev.org/openstack/requirements/src/branch/master/upper-constraints.txt#L361'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-06-20 16:18:41.000000000', 'message': "vif: Stop using getattr for VIF lookups

'getattr' is really powerful and we make extensive use of it in nova.
However, the way we've used it for VIF lookup, where we use it to
retrieve functions by a key, seems to be a bit of an anti-pattern. Not
only does it completely breaks static code coverage analysers that we
can use to help us root out code that's not tested or is tested but is
never used in production but, more importantly, it make it so much more
difficult to figure out what on earth is going on in an already complex
part of the codebase.

Be verbose and, in the absence of a true switch statement in Python, use
simple if-else blocks to do the lookups. Due to how this is done, we're
able to remove a few previously no-op functions. Funnily enough, this
actually results in fewer LOC despite being more explicit. #winning?

Change-Id: Idf08adca1e3a0d19e20bca2447c83f7372516cb7
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>

commit_message:
vif: Stop using getattr for VIF lookups

'getattr' is really powerful and we make extensive use of it in nova.
However, the way we've used it for VIF lookups, where we use it to
retrieve functions by a key, seems to be a bit of an anti-pattern. Not
only does it completely break static code coverage analysers that we can
use to help us root out code that's not tested (or is tested but is
never used in production) but, more importantly, it makes it so much
more difficult to figure out what on earth is going on in an already
complex part of the codebase.

Be verbose and, in the absence of a true switch statement in Python, use
simple if-else blocks to do the lookups. Due to how this is done, we're
able to remove a few previously no-op functions. Funnily enough, this
actually results in fewer LOC despite being more explicit. #winning?

Change-Id: Idf08adca1e3a0d19e20bca2447c83f7372516cb7
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>
